awd_titl_txt: Unraveling the history of the Greenland Ice Sheet from its internal radiostratigraphy
awd_abstract_narration:
The internal structure of glaciers and ice sheets, revealed by ice-penetrating radars, has transformed our ability to understand ice evolution. Two investigators propose to use a recently developed compilation of available radar data from Greenland, in combination with ice-flow models, to increase understanding of the history of the Greenland Ice Sheet that will provide context for its response to current and future changes. This is the first time such a project is possible across most of the Greenland Ice Sheet to address how the climate and the ice sheet have changed over time.
 
The major objectives of the proposed work include: 1) validating inferences from the recently available ice-sheet-wide dated radiostratigraphy of the Greenland Ice Sheet against those from internal reflections mapped by targeted ground-based and airborne data collected along flowlines; 2) defining and applying strategies to use Greenland Ice Sheet radiostratigraphy; to constrain its history and to evaluate hypotheses regarding its evolution; 3) determining reconstructions of Greenland's past climate and ice flow that match the radiostratigraphy; and 4) providing a foundation for future continental-scale ice-flow modeling that will seek to assimilate an extensive radiostratigraphy. Broader impacts will include support of two early-career investigators, mentoring graduate and undergraduate students, public outreach, and incorporation of the research into formal classes.

por.por_cntn:
Internal structure of glaciers and ice sheets revealed by ice-penetrating radars has transformed our ability to understand ice evolution, and internal reflections imaged across large portions of the Greenland Ice Sheet are an excellent spatially resolved record of annual to multi-millennial change in Greenland. In this project we used the radiostragraphy archive for Greenland to constrain ice-sheet history. Improved reconstructions of the last deglaciation and Holocene behavior in Greenland are important toward understanding the modern ice-sheet state and for making projections. We found that along a flowline in northern Greenland the modeled layers west of the modern divide are too deep, and that this could indicate the divide stays east of the modern at ~10 ka. We also found that along a flowline in southern Greenland the modeled layers west of the modern divide are too shallow, which could indicate the divide stays west of the modern at ~10 ka. We identified that the state-of-the-art continent-scale reconstruction includes interior ice-sheet geometry changes that are inconsistent with available internal structure -- through our work we provided specific inconsistencies that can be used to improve ice-sheet reconstructions.

In addition to large scale variability in englacial layer shape, we explored short wavelength features within the shear margins of the Northeast Greenland Ice Stream. Not captured in the gridded layer surfaces that are available at the continent scale, short wavelength features can reveal local variability in bed strength, ice viscosity, or accumulation that result from poorly understood processes within shear margins, near grounding zones, and at the stagnant / sliding transition.

As we proposed as part of the Broader Impacts on this award, the PI organized and led a 4-week study abroad opportunity to Greenland and Denmark for 14 University of Washington undergraduate students. The group traveled along the west coast of Greenland, and also spent one week in Copenhagen; the course focus was on ice and climate change and how that affects society. During the travels the group met with scientists, politicians, educators, community activists, artists, and citizens of Greenland and Denmark to learn from and share perspectives on environmental change and life in the Arctic. In addition to this course the PI organized a follow-on seminar for the students, and has been invited to share on this experience at multiple events and an educators workshop in Greenland, as well as write a popular science article on changes in the Greenland Ice Sheet. All team members engage in outreach activity to the local community, as well as sharing research results with undergraduate and graduate students through University courses.


Last Modified: 12/30/2019
Modified by: Michelle R Koutnik
